{{italic title}} {{Use British English|date=May 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox Website | name = ''Spiked'' | favicon = | logo = Spikedlogo.png | logo_size = 157px | screenshot = | caption = | url = [http://spiked-online.com spiked-online.com] | commercial = No | type = Politics | registration = No | owner = [[Brendan O'Neill (journalist)|Brendan O'Neill]] | author = [[Mick Hume]] |alexa = {{Increase}} 84,689 ({{as of|2018|11|26|alt=Nov 2018}}){{cite web|url=http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/spiked-online.com|title=spiked-online.com Site Overview|publisher=[[Alexa Internet]]|accessdate=26 November 2018}} | launch date = 2000 | current status = | revenue = }} '''''Spiked''''' (also written as '''''sp!ked''''') is a British [[online magazine|Internet magazine]] focusing on politics, culture and society. == Editors and contributors == ''Spiked'' is edited by [[Brendan O'Neill (journalist)|Brendan O'Neill]],{{cite web | url = http://www.spiked-online.com/index.php?/about/article/193/ | title = Frequently asked questions | work = Spiked | accessdate =14 April 2007 }} following [[Mick Hume]]'s departure in January 2007, and features regular contributions from [[James Heartfield]], [[Michael Fitzpatrick (physician)|Michael Fitzpatrick]], [[Patrick West]], Rob Lyons, Nathalie Rothschild, Tim Black, Duleep Allirajah, Tom Slater, Joanna Williams and [[Frank Furedi]]. == Origin == The magazine was founded in 2000 after the [[bankruptcy]] of its predecessor, ''[[Living Marxism]]'' (''LM'').{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsws.org/en/articles/2016/05/31/spik-m31.html|title=The politics and origins of Britain’s Spiked-Online—Part Two|last=Reed|first=Zach|access-date=2018-05-24}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.lrb.co.uk/v32/n13/jenny-turner/who-are-they|title=Who Are They?|last=Ideas|first=Jenny Turner reports from the Battle of|date=2010-07-08|work=London Review of Books|access-date=2018-05-24|pages=3–8|issn=0260-9592}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.spiked-online.com/newsite/article/8323#.WwaXoUiUvZs|title=Why we were right to fight|website=www.spiked-online.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-05-24}} ''LM'' closed after losing a [[English defamation law|libel]] case brought against it by the broadcasting corporation [[ITN]]. The case centred around ITN coverage of [[Fikret Alić]] and other Bosnian Muslims standing behind a barbed-wire fence at the [[Trnopolje camp]] during the [[Yugoslav war]]. ''LM'' opposed Western intervention on traditional anti-imperialist grounds, and thus warned against the tendency to moralise the conflict – with Muslims portrayed as the victims and [[Serbs]] as the villains – which was fuelling the clamour for military action. ''LM'' published an article titled "The Picture that Fooled the World"{{cite news |url=http://www.informinc.co.uk/LM/LM97/LM97_Bosnia.html |title='The Picture that Fooled the World' |first=Thomas | last=Deichman |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19991110185707/http://www.informinc.co.uk/LM/LM97/LM97_Bosnia.html |archivedate=10 November 1999}} which claimed that ITN's coverage was deceptive, the barbed-wire did not enclose the camp and the Muslims were in fact "refugees, many of whom went there seeking safety and could leave again if they wished." During the court case, evidence given by the camp doctor led LM to abandon its defence. ITN was awarded damages and costs, estimated to be around £1 million.{{cite news |url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/article419696.ece|title = The day I faced being a £1m bankrupt|date = 7 March 2005|first = Mick|last = Hume|work = The Times|accessdate = 14 April 2007|location = London|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110523235709/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/article419696.ece|archive-date = 23 May 2011}} == Stance == ''Spiked'' focuses on issues of freedom and state control, science and technology, culture, education and literature. The magazine opposes all forms of censorship, by the state or otherwise. Its writers call for a repeal of [[libel]],{{cite web | url = http://www.spiked-online.com/index.php?/site/article/935/ | title = Don’t tinker with the libel laws – scrap them | first = Helene | last = Guldberg | date = 6 July 2006 | work = Spiked | accessdate =14 April 2007 }} [[hate speech]]{{cite web | url = http://www.spiked-online.com/index.php?/site/article/34/ | title = Sticks, stones and hate speech | work = Spiked | first = Josie | last = Appleton | date = 11 April 2006 | accessdate =14 April 2007 }} and [[incitement]]{{cite web | title = Free speech, with the edges taken off | url = http://www.spiked-online.com/index.php?/site/article/273/ | first = Brendan | last = O’Neill | date = 28 March 2006 | work = Spiked |accessdate =14 April 2007 }}{{cite web | title = Can music incite murder? | url = http://www.spiked-online.com/Articles/0000000CA733.htm | first = Brendan | last = O’Neill | date = 13 October 2004 | accessdate =14 April 2007 | work = Spiked }} laws, and of censorship on university campuses (e.g. [[No Platform]]).[http://www.spiked-online.com/down-with-campus-censorship-campaign Down with campus censorship! Campaign]. ''Sp!ked'' official website. Retrieved 24 May 2018. They have criticised laws targeted at paedophiles as counterproductive to rehabilitation and conducive to mob violence.{{cite web | title = The return of the paedophile panic | url = http://www.spiked-online.com/index.php?/site/article/4557/ | first = Tim | last = Black | date = 19 February 2008 | accessdate =23 August 2017 | work = Spiked }} ''Spiked'' also regularly critiques [[risk society]], [[political correctness]], and environmentalism. As regards the latter, a particular ''Spiked'' target has been what they see as "exaggerated" and "hysterical" interpretations of the scientific consensus on [[global warming]], and what they argue are double-standards advocated by more advanced Western nations for self-serving reasons.{{cite web |last = Woudhuysen and Kaplinsky | title = After the IPCC: A man-made morality tale | url = http://www.spiked-online.com/index.php?/site/article/2819/ | work = Spiked |accessdate =15 July 2006 }} ''Spiked'' opposed the post-[[September 11, 2001 attacks|9/11]] invasions [[United States invasion of Afghanistan|of Afghanistan]] and [[2003 invasion of Iraq|of Iraq]] and Western interference in [[developing nations]] in general.{{cite web |author1=Nadine Strossen |author2=Faisal Devji |author3=Jeffrey Rosen |author4=Brendan O'Neill |author5=Michael Baum | title = Life, liberty and politics after 9/11 | url = http://www.spiked-online.com/index.php?/site/article/1602/ | work = Spiked |accessdate =15 July 2006 |display-authors=etal}}{{cite web |last = Hume |first=Mick | title = The age of PR imperialism | url = http://www.spiked-online.com/index.php?/site/article/2120/ | work = Spiked |accessdate =15 July 2006 }}{{cite web |last = Cunliffe |first=Philip | title = Exposing ‘Empire in denial’ | url = http://www.spiked-online.com/index.php?/site/article/1601/ | work = Spiked |accessdate =15 July 2006 }} It seeks to counter what it sees as a recent trend in Western foreign policy: [[humanitarian intervention]].{{cite web |last = O'Neill and Brendan | title = What's worse than a Blairite? A Blair-basher | url = http://www.spiked-online.com/index.php?/site/article/3331/ | work = Spiked |accessdate =10 May 2007 }} Some have said that ''Spiked'''s stance has more in common with libertarianism than with the mainstream left.For example, in a [[LobbyWatch]] interview, George Monbiot claimed of ''Spiked's'' predecessor, ''[[LM Magazine]]'', that: "...it was very far from a Marxism journal – it was just about as far from a Marxist journal as you could possibly get."{{cite news | url = http://www.lobbywatch.org/archive2.asp?arcid=7748 | title = Interview with George Monbiot | first = George | last = Monbiot | publisher = [[LobbyWatch]] | accessdate =14 August 2010 }} Frank Furedi, interviewed in ''Spiked'', responded that the stance of ''LM'' and ''Spiked'' springs from the tradition of the "[[anti-Stalinist left]]". He argued that the reason why many in the left tradition have difficulties in identifying these ideas with the left is that they completely misunderstand the humanist political position of being progressive in terms of human progress, science, rationality and freedom, and yet be completely anti-state:
...much of the left in the twentieth century tended to be influenced by Stalinist and Social-Democratic traditions, which means they could not imagine that you could be left-wing and anti-state...so they were confused by us. But that was their fault, not ours. It was a product of their own abandonment of liberty in favour of ideas about state control.{{cite news | url = http://www.spiked-online.com/index.php?/site/article/3132/ | title = 'Humanising politics – that is my only agenda' | first = Brendan | last = O'Neill | publisher = Spiked | accessdate = 27 April 2007 }}
Environmentalists such as [[George Monbiot]]Monbiot, George (9 December 2003). [https://www.theguardian.com/education/2003/dec/09/highereducation.uk2 "Invasion of the entryists"]. ''The Guardian'' (London). and [[Peter Melchett]] have suggested that the group of writers associated with ''LM'', several of whom went on to form the core editorial group at Spiked, continue to constitute a 'LM Network' pursuing an ideologically motivated '[[Anti-environmentalism|anti-environmentalist]]' agenda under the guise of promoting [[Humanism]].Melchett, Peter (19 April 2007). [http://commentisfree.guardian.co.uk/peter_melchett/2007/04/farming_for_the_future.html "Clear intentions"]. ''The Guardian'' (London).[http://www.lobbywatch.org/profile1.asp?PrId=39 Profiles: Martin Durkin], [http://www.lobbywatch.org/lm_intro.html LobbyWatch]. Retrieved 17 April 2007. Writers who used to write for ''Living Marxism'' reject this as a 'McCarthyite' conspiracy theory.{{cite news |url= http://www.spiked-online.com/index.php?/site/article/3132/ |date=25 April 2007 |title= 'Humanising politics—that is my only agenda' |first= Brendan |last= O'Neill |work= Spiked Online |accessdate=27 April 2007}} Monbiot described their views as having, "less in common with the left than with the fanatical right."{{cite news |url =http://www.monbiot.com/archives/1998/11/01/far-left-or-far-right/ |title=Far Left or Far Right? |date=1 November 1998 |first= George |last= Monbiot |work= [[Prospect (magazine)|Prospect]] |location =London}} ==''Spiked Review of Books''== [[Image:SRB masthead.gif|thumb|right]] The ''Spiked Review of Books'' is a monthly online [[literary criticism]] feature, based at ''Spiked''. The launch in May 2007 coincided with controversy in the United States following the scaling back of newspaper [[book review]] sections.[http://www.bookcritics.org/?go=saveBookReviews The National Book Critics Circle's Campaign to Save Book Reviews], John Freeman, President, National Book Critics Circle. The ''Spiked Review of Books'' features editorials by Brendan O'Neill and interviews, essays and reviews by a range of writers, many of whom are regular contributors to ''Spiked'', such as Frank Furedi, Jennie Bristow and Josie Appleton. The cover illustrations are by Jan Bowman. == Funding == ''Spiked'' receives its funding via the organising of debates, surveys, seminars and conferences, with a variety of partners, sponsors and organisations. It also receives donations from readers.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} ==References== {{Reflist|3}} ==External links== *[http://www.spiked-online.com/ ''Sp!ked'' Online] *[http://www.spiked-online.com/freespeechnow Free speech now!] - a ''sp!ked'' project *[http://www.frankfuredi.com Frank Furedi official website] *[http://www.woudhuysen.com James Woudhuysen website] *[http://www.heartfield.org/ James Heartfield website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Spiked (Magazine)}} [[Category:2000 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:British online magazines]] [[Category:British political magazines]] [[Category:Freedom of speech in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Magazines established in 2000]] [[Category:Organizations of environmentalism skeptics and critics]] [[Category:Politics and technology]]

{{Infobox political youth organization | name = Students For Trump | logo = |chairman = Ryan Fournier (NC) |headquarters = [[Raleigh, NC]] |mother party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] |website = [https://studentsfortrump.net www.studentsfortrump.net] }}
'''Students for Trump''' ('''S4T''') is an American [[Political organization|non-profit political organization]] whose stated mission is to "see that [[Donald Trump]] is elected as the next President of the United States and that the Republican Party is placed back into power in Washington." The group was founded in 2015 by Ryan Fournier and John Lambert, students at [[Campbell University]] in [[North Carolina]], [[United States]].<ref name="IBT">{{cite news |first=Julia |last=Glum |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/students-trump-meet-millennials-helping-donald-nab-youth-vote-2206369 |title=Students For Trump: Meet The Millennials Helping The Donald Nab The Youth Vote |work=[[International Business Times]] |date=December 1, 2015 |access-date=June 15, 2018}}</ref>
The organization recruits Campus Ambassadors at college and high school campuses across the country, and encourages chapters to participate in on-campus advocacy, host events, and persuade students to vote for [[Donald Trump]]. Currently, the organization reports that it has over 5,000 volunteers, 280 chapters, and over 13,000 vote pledges.{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}}
== History == The organization was founded in 2015 by Fournier and Lambert, students at [[Campbell University]] in [[North Carolina]], [[United States]].<ref name="IBT" />
In 2016, the organization switched from a traditional campaign model with Regional, State, and Chapter coordinators, to a model with Campus Ambassadors that perform roles similar to that of a campaign field [[intern]].
== Organizational structure == The following people comprise the organization's national leadership team: * Ryan Fournier (National Chairman) * Sarah Hagmayer (Public Relations Coordinator)<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-intersect/wp/2016/07/18/meet-the-9-people-helping-donald-trump-win-the-internet/|title=A revealing look into Donald Trump's unofficial Internet campaign|last=Dewey|first=Caitlin|date=July 18, 2016|last2=Ohlheiser|first2=Abby|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286|access-date=July 21, 2016}}</ref> In addition to the national team, the group has Campus Ambassadors on 280 college campuses across the country as of July 20, 2016.
== Projects ==
=== [[Chalkening|The Chalkening]] === In March and April 2016, college students at universities across the United States used chalk to write slogans in support of [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|Donald Trump's presidential campaign]]. The event was publicized on [[Twitter]] by Dan Scavino and the Students for Trump official account.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.alternet.org/tea-party-and-right/trumps-call-college-supporters-express-themselves-chalk-leaves-campuses-full|title=Trump's Call for College Supporters to Express Themselves With Chalk Leaves Campuses Full of Racist Messages|last=Tesfaye|first=Sophia|date=April 11, 2016|newspaper=[[AlterNet]]|access-date=July 21, 2016}}</ref>
The event, and ensuing student reaction, led to [[DePaul University]] to ban the use of chalk on campus property.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2016/apr/15/depaul-bans-chalking-after-pro-trump-messages/|title=DePaul U. bans use of chalk on sidewalks after pro-Trump messages offend|work=[[The Washington Times]]|access-date=July 21, 2016|date=April 15, 2016|first=Kelly|last=Riddell}}</ref>
=== "Trump Wall" events === On May 9, 2016, a group of students at the [[University of Washington]] constructed an 8'x10' "Trump Wall" out of plywood and lumber in the center of the [[Red Square (University of Washington)|Red Square]] courtyard. The event, led by UW [[College Republicans]] president Jessie Gamble, UW Students for Trump president Chevy Swanson, and S4T senior advisor [[James Allsup]], lasted for an approximately an hour and a half, and was met with ten Trump supporters and over 100 protestors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.seattleweekly.com/news/the-uw-trump-movement-is-a-perfect-microcosm-of-the-donalds-ridiculous-campaign/|title=The UW Trump Movement Is a Perfect Microcosm of the Donald's Ridiculous Campaign |work=[[Seattle Weekly]]|date=May 20, 2016|language=en-US|access-date=July 21, 2016}}</ref>
The wall was painted with a brick design, with "[[Trump wall|Trump Wall]]" written in gold paint, and "[[Blue Lives Matter|Blues Lives Matter]]" and "[[Make America Great Again]]" written in blue. At one point, a student attempted to scale the wall. Shortly after this, the organizers were asked by the University Police to take the wall down, which they did.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/education/students-erect-trump-wall-at-the-university-of-washington/|title=College students erect 'Trump wall' at University of Washington|date=May 9, 2016|access-date=July 21, 2016|work=[[The Seattle Times]]|first=Katherine|last=Long}}</ref>
[[Portland State University]] Students for Trump, a group unaffiliated with the S4T national organization, hosted a similar event on June 10, 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://katu.com/news/local/psu-students-for-donald-trump-group-builds-wall-at-rally|title=PSU 'Students for Donald Trump' group builds wall at rally|work=[[KATU]]|language=en-US|access-date=July 21, 2016|date=June 10, 2016}}</ref> The wall was smaller at this event, and beforehand organizers announced on [[Facebook]] that "[[Mexico]] and [[Black Lives Matter]] are going to need help paying for the wall so we'll be holding a collection."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rawstory.com/2016/06/meet-the-shock-troops-of-trumps-america/|title=Meet the shock troops of Trump's America|website=[[The Raw Story]]|access-date=July 21, 2016|date=June 17, 2016|first=Arun|last=Gupta}}</ref>
== Controversy ==
In April 2016, a Students for Trump [[Florida]] chapter placed a "Make America Great Again" ball cap on a statue of [[Martin Luther King Jr.]] just days after the anniversary of his death. This caused a wide array of social media attacks towards the organization.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/photo-shows-martin-luther-king-statue-donald-trump-hat-article-1.2596077|title='Students for Trump' group posts photo of Martin Luther King statue wearing 'Make America Great Again' hat on University of South Florida campus |work=[[New York Daily News]]|date=April 11, 2016|language=en-US|access-date=July 21, 2016|first=Jason|last=Silverstein}}</ref>

[[image:TFOI 300.png|thumb|Terror-Free Oil]] The '''Terror-Free Oil Initiative''' was a group based in [[Coral Springs, Florida]], dedicated to encouraging Americans to buy only [[gasoline]] that originated in countries that do not export or finance [[terrorism]]<ref name="soleil">{{cite news|publisher=Le Soleil|date=2007-01-23|title=Du pétrole sans terreur dans le Nebraska}}</ref> or are otherwise unfriendly towards the United States.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.terrorfreeoil.com/about.php | title = About TFO }}</ref>
It promoted those companies that acquire their [[Petroleum|crude oil]] supply from the nations outside [[Middle East]] and criticized those companies that do not.<ref name="newsnet">{{cite web| url =http://www.newsnet5.com/money/10815377/detail.html | title = Gas Station To Offer 'Terror-Free' Oil|publisher=newsnet5.com|date=2007-01-22}}</ref>
TFOI attempted to create a healthy debate concerning alternate methods of fuel production and consumption.<ref name="newsnet" />
Terror-Free Oil opened the first "terror free" gas station in [[Omaha, Nebraska]], in January 2007. In February 2010 the station closed.<ref name="soleil" /><ref name="newsnet" />
TFO spokesman Joe Kaufman is also the founder of a group called Americans Against Hate, a conservative civil rights organization and terrorism watchdog group.{{citation needed|date=October 2013}} Kaufman is a prominent critic of the [[Islamic]] advocacy organization [[Council on American-Islamic Relations]].
== Criticism ==
Terror-Free Oil purchased its gas from [[Sinclair Oil Corporation]], who buy oil from all areas of the world on the [[New York Mercantile Exchange]]. After critics questioned the buying methods of the group, founder Joe Kaufman, was forced to acknowledge that the stations were likely selling some oil from the Middle East.<ref name="APM"/>
Journalist and writer on energy, [[Robert Bryce (writer)|Robert Bryce]] also criticised the group on the [[American Public Media]] show [[Marketplace (radio program)|Marketplace]]<ref name="APM">{{cite news|url=http://marketplace.publicradio.org/shows/2007/02/12/PM200702124.html|title=Pumping a message to fuel sales|date=2007-02-12|publisher=[[American Public Media]]|accessdate=2009-05-13}}</ref> and the [[CNBC]] show, ''Closing Bell with Maria Bartiromo''.<ref name="CNBC">{{cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/15840232?video=221073758&play=1|title=Terror-Free Oil|date=2007-03-20|publisher=CNBC|accessdate=2009-05-13}}</ref> Bryce stated that "the trends of energy interdependence are growing and are inexorable" and branded that idea of being able choose where your oil came from as "hogwash".
==References== <references />

{{short description|1973 French anti-immigration novel by Jean Raspail}} {{infobox book| | name = The Camp of the Saints | title_orig = Le Camp des Saints | translator = Norman Shapiro | image = File:TheCampOfTheSaints.jpg | border = yes | caption = Cover of the first edition | author = [[Jean Raspail]] | country = France | language = French | publisher = [[Éditions Robert Laffont]] | release_date = 1973 | english_release_date = 1975 | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover|Hardback]] & [[Paperback]]) | pages = | isbn = 0-684-14240-6 | dewey = 843/.9/14 | congress = PZ4.R227 Cam PQ2635.A379 | oclc = 1174645 }}
'''''The Camp of the Saints''''' ({{lang-fr|Le Camp des Saints}}) is a 1973 French novel by author and explorer [[Jean Raspail]]. The novel depicts the destruction of [[Western civilization]] through [[Third World]] mass immigration to [[France]] and the [[Western world|West]]. Almost forty years after its initial publication, the novel returned to the bestseller list in 2011.<ref name="L'Express">''[[L'Express]]'': [http://www.lexpress.fr/culture/livre/le-camp-des-saints-de-jean-raspail-un-succes-de-librairie-raciste_980039.html "Le camp des Saints, de Jean Raspail, un succès de librairie raciste?"], 6 April 2011, retrieved 30 November 2012</ref> On its publication, the book received praise from some French literary figures<ref>"''Le camp des saints'' finit par obtenir une critique imposante, non pas tant par le volume (demeuré incomparable à celui que provoque le moindre texte d'une vedette de variétés) que par la qualité de ses laudateurs. Ils s'appellent Anouilh, Bazin, Cau, Clavel, Déon, Dutourd, Fourastié, Maulnier, Pauwels..." {{cite book |last1=Deschodt |first1=Eric |title=Utopies en noir |date=April 1985 |publisher=Le Spectacle du monde |pages=71 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i-07AQAAIAAJ |language=fr}}</ref><ref>"arrives trailing clouds of praise from French savants, including Dramatist [[Jean Anouilh]]" {{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,913401,00.html|title=Poor White Trash|author=Paul Gray|date=1975-08-04|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|accessdate=2014-01-27|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070815090521/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,913401,00.html|archivedate=August 15, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref>, including [[Jean Anouilh|Anouilh]], [[Hervé_Bazin|Bazin]], [[Jean_Cau_(writer)|Cau]], [[Maurice_Clavel|Clavel]], [[Michel_Déon|Deón]], [[Jean_Dutourd|Dutourd]], [[Jean Fourastié|Fourastié]], [[Thierry_Maulnier|Maulnier]], and [[Louis_Pauwels|Pauwels]]. In the U.S., it was praised by William F. Buckley and [[Max_Lerner|Max Lerner]], and criticized by [[Linda_Chavez|Linda Chavez]] and the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]].
== Inspiration == Raspail has said his inspiration came while at the French Riviera in 1971, as he was looking out at the Mediterranean.
{{Quote|What if ''they'' were to come? I did not know who "they" were, but it seemed inevitable to me that the numberless disinherited people of the South would, like a tidal wave, set sail one day for this opulent shore, our fortunate country’s wide-gaping frontier.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Le Camp des Saints (Édition 2011)|last=Raspail|first=John|publisher=|year=|isbn=978-1881780076|location=|pages=}}</ref>}}
The name of the book comes from a passage in the [[Book of Revelation]] (Revelation 20:7–9) depicting the [[apocalypse]]. Satan influences most of the nations of the Earth to gather for one final battle against "the camp of the saints," before being defeated for eternity:
{{Quote|And when the thousand years are ended, Satan will be released from his prison and will come out to deceive the nations that are at the four corners of the earth, Gog and Magog, to gather them for battle; their number is like the sand of the sea. And they marched up over the broad plain of the earth and surrounded the camp of the saints and the beloved city, but fire came down from heaven and consumed them...<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bible.com/bible/59/REV.20.esv|title=Revelation 20, English Standard Version (ESV) {{!}} Chapter 20 {{!}} The Bible App {{!}} Bible.com|website=www.bible.com|language=en|access-date=2017-10-12}}</ref>}}
== Plot == {{Long plot|section|date=February 2018}}
In [[Kolkata|Calcutta, India]], [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] priests promote the adoption of Indian children by those back in [[Belgium]] as a form of charity. When the Belgian government realizes that the number of Indian children raised in Belgium has reached 40,000 in just five years, an emergency policy attempts to halt the migration. Desperate for the chance to send their children to what they call a "land of plenty", a mob of desperate Indians swarms the [[consulate]]. As a Belgian aid worker works through the crowd, an Indian [[gong farmer]] begs him to take them back to Europe, to which the worker agrees.
The worker and farmer bring the crowd to the docks, where there are hundreds of ships once owned by European powers, now suited only for river traffic. Nevertheless, the crowd boards, and a hundred ships soon leave for Europe; conditions on board are cramped, unsanitary and miserable, with some passengers publicly fornicating. As the ships pass "the straits of [[Sri Lanka|Ceylon]]", helicopters swarm overhead, capturing images of the refugees on board to be published in Europe. Meanwhile, on the [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Russian]] Far East, the Soviet troops see masses of Chinese ready to enter [[Siberia]] but are reluctant to fight them.
As the fleet crosses the Indian Ocean, the political situation in France becomes more charged. At a press conference about the crisis, a French official who offers a speech in praise of the refugees is confronted by a journalist who claims he is merely trying to "feed the invaders" and demands to know if France will "have the courage to stand up to" the migrants when they reach France. The official decries this question as morally offensive and threatens to throw the journalist out when he continues to yell. Other journalists seek to inflame tensions between the French and Africans and Arabs already living in the country. Over time, these journalists begin to write that the migrant fleet is on a mission to "enrich, cleanse and redeem the Capitalist West". At the same time as the fleet is praised by those in Paris, the people of [[Southern France]], terrified of the migrants' arrival, flee to the north.
As the fleet approaches the [[Suez Canal]], [[Egypt|Egyptian]] forces fire a warning shot, causing the fleet to steer south, around the [[Cape of Good Hope]]. To the surprise of observers, the [[apartheid]] regime of [[South Africa]] floats out barges of food and supplies, which the migrants throw overboard. The international press is thrilled, believing the rejection of these supplies to be a political statement against the apartheid South African regime. Western leaders, confident the refugees will accept supplies from their "more virtuous" nations, organize a supply mission, funded by governments, charities, rock stars and major churches, to meet the refugees off [[São Tomé and Príncipe|São Tomé]]. However, the fleet does not stop for these barges either, and when a worker from the [[Pope|Papal]] barge attempts to board one of the ships, he is strangled and thrown overboard. The press attempts to contain coverage of the disaster.
When the migrants pass through the [[Strait of Gibraltar]], the [[President of France|French president]] orders troops to the south and addresses the nation of his plan to repel the migrants. However, in the middle of the address, he breaks down, demands the troops simply follow their consciences instead. Most of the troops immediately desert their posts and join the civilians as they flee north, and the south is quickly overrun by the migrants. Some of the last troops to stand their ground take refuge in a small village, along with Calguès, an old man who has chosen to remain at his home, and Hamadura, a [[Westernization|Westernized]] Indian who is terrified of his "filthy, brutish" countrymen and prides himself on having more in common with whites than Indians. The troops in this village, total of nineteen Frenchmen and one Indian, surrounded by what they deem "occupied territory", remains the last defense of Western values and "Free France" against the immigrants.
The migrants make their way north, having no desire to assimilate to French culture, but continuing to demand a First World standard of living, even as they flout laws, do not produce, and murder French citizens, such as factory bosses and shopkeepers, as well as the ordinary people who do not welcome them. They are also joined by the immigrants who already reside in Europe, as well as various left-wing and anarchist groups. Across the West, more and more migrants arrive and have children, rapidly growing to outnumber whites. In a matter of months, the white West has been overrun and the pro-immigrant governments are established, while the white people are ordered to share their houses and flats with the immigrants. The village containing the troops is bombed flat by airplanes of the new French government, referred to only as the "Paris Multiracial Commune". Within a few years, most Western governments have surrendered. The mayor of [[New York City]] is made to share [[Gracie Mansion]] with three [[African-American]] families from [[Harlem]], migrants gather at coastal ports in West Africa and South Asia and swarm into [[Europe]], [[Australia]], and [[New Zealand]], London is taken over by an organization of non-white residents known as the "Non-European Commonwealth Committee" which force the [[Elizabeth II|British queen]] to have her son marry a [[Pakistan]]i woman, millions of [[black Africans]] from around the continent gather at the [[Limpopo River]] and invade [[apartheid]] [[South Africa]], and only one drunken [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] soldier stands in the way of hundreds of thousands of Chinese peasants as they overrun Siberia.
The epilogue reveals that the story was written in the last holdout of the Western world, [[Switzerland]], but international pressure from the new governments, isolating it as a [[rogue state]] for not opening its borders, and the internal pro-migrant elements, force it to capitulate as well. Mere hours from the border opening, the author dedicates the book to his grandchildren, in the hopes they will grow up in a world where they will not be ashamed of him for writing such a book.
== English translations == A translation by Norman Shapiro was published by [[Charles Scribner's Sons|Scribner]] in 1975 ({{ISBN|0-684-14240-6}}). It was republished in [[mass market paperback]] format by [[Ace Books]] in 1977 ({{ISBN|0-441-09120-2}}), and in softcover format by [[The Social Contract Press]] in 1995 ({{ISBN|1-881780-07-4}}). The novel is also available in [[Amazon Kindle]] format.<ref>https://www.amazon.com/Camp-Saints-Jean-Raspail-ebook/dp/B00QKNDV9S/</ref>
== Reception == According to historian of literature [[:fr:Jean-Marc Moura|Jean-Marc Moura]],<ref name=moura>"... a connu de nombreuses traductions et, en France, un accueil critique favorable" p. 124 {{cite journal |last1=Moura |first1=Jean-Marc |title=Littérature et idéologie de la migration : « Le camp des Saints » de Jean Raspail |journal=Revue européenne des migrations internationales |date=1988 |volume=4 |issue=3 |pages=115–124 |doi=10.3406/remi.1988.1182 |url=https://www.persee.fr/doc/remi_0765-0752_1988_num_4_3_1182 |language=fr-FR |issn=0765-0752}}</ref> ''The Camp of the Saints'' received a positive reception, with most critics focusing on the "prophetic" nature of the story. According to [[Matthew Connelly]] and [[Paul Kennedy]], "[s]ixties radicalism still prevailed in Paris... [and] French intellectuals and bureaucrats swiftly dismissed [the book] as a racist tract".<ref name="atlantic"/> It was praised by [[Bernard Pivot]] and conservative intellectuals such as [[Michel Déon]], [[Jean Cau (writer)|Jean Cau]] and [[Louis Pauwels]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Le Point|date=1987|pages=5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3YY7AQAAIAAJ|language=fr}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Dupuis|first1=Jerome|title=Le camp des Saints, de Jean Raspail, un succès de librairie raciste?|publisher=L'Express|url=http://www.lexpress.fr/culture/livre/le-camp-des-saints-de-jean-raspail-un-succes-de-librairie-raciste_980039.html|language=fr}}</ref> After it was translated to English, [[Max Lerner]] said that it had "irresistible pace of skill and narrative", while [[Sidney Hook]] said that it would "succeed in shocking and challenging the complacent contemporary mind".<ref>{{cite book|title=Publishers Weekly|publisher=R. R. Bowker Company|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EcBEAQAAIAAJ|language=en}}</ref> In 1975, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine panned the novel as a "bilious tirade" that only required a response because it "arrives trailing clouds of praise from French savants, including Dramatist [[Jean Anouilh]] ('A haunting book of irresistible force and calm logic'), with the imprint of a respected U.S. publisher and a teasing pre-publication ad campaign ('The end of the white world is near')".<ref name="time">{{cite news|author=Paul Gray |title=Poor White Trash |date=1975-08-04 |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,913401,00.html |accessdate=2014-01-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070815090521/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,913401,00.html |archivedate=August 15, 2007 }}</ref> ''[[Kirkus Reviews]]'' compared the novel to ''[[Mein Kampf]]'',<ref name=Kirkus>[https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/jean-raspail-2/the-camp-of-the-saints/ The Camp of the Saints], reviewed in [[Kirkus Reviews]], published July 28, 1975; retrieved from Kirkus Online, March 5, 2017</ref> while [[Jeffrey Hart]] in the ''[[National Review]]'' mocked the rejection of the novel by critics - deriding them as "respectable, comfortable reviewers" - and lauded the book, stating "in freer and more intelligent circles in Europe, the book is a sensation and Raspail is a prize-winner [...] his plot is both simple and brilliant".<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hart|first=Jeffrey|date=26 September 1975|title=Raspail's Superb Scandal|url=|journal=National Review|volume=27|pages=1062-63|via=}}</ref> Syndicated columnist [[Garry Wills]] condemned the embrace of the novel by the "more 'respectable' channels" of American right-wing media, including Hart, drawing parallels between the "racial implications" of the book and the ''National Review'''s "overtly racist analysis" of school integration efforts.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wills|first=Garry|date=23 October 1975|title=The Right and Racism|url=|journal=Manchester Journal Inquirer|volume=|pages=27|via=}}</ref> In 1983, [[Linda Chavez]] called the novel "a sickening book", describing it as "racist, xenophobic and paranoid".<ref>{{cite book |first=James |last=Crawford |title=Language Loyalties: A Source Book on the Official English Controversy |location= |publisher=University of Chicago Press |year=1992 |isbn= 0226120163 |page=174 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=wLoJ31HXl40C&lpg=PA174&dq=%22racist%2C%20xenophobic%20and%20paranoid%22%20Linda%20Chavez&pg=PA174#v=onepage&q=%22racist,%20xenophobic%20and%20paranoid%22%20Linda%20Chavez&f=true }}</ref> The December 1994 cover story of ''[[The Atlantic Monthly]]'' focused on the themes of the novel, analyzing them in the context of [[international relations]], while describing it as "the most politically incorrect book in France in the second half of the twentieth century".<ref name="atlantic">{{cite news|author= Matthew Connelly and Paul Kennedy|title=Must It Be the Rest Against the West?|date=December 1994|work=[[Atlantic Monthly]]|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/past/politics/immigrat/kennf.htm|accessdate=2009-04-09}}</ref> This was at about the same time that [[The Social Contract Press]] chose to bring it back into U.S. publication.<ref name="scp">{{cite news|author= John Tanton|title=The Puppeteer Replies - The Social Contract Press|work=[[The Social Contract Press]]|url=http://www.thesocialcontract.com/answering_our_critics/puppeteer.html#camp|accessdate=2009-04-09}}</ref>
In 2001, the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] described it as "widely revered by American white supremacists and is a sort of anti-immigration analog to ''[[The Turner Diaries]]'',"<ref>[https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/intelligence-report/2015/racist-book-camp-saints-gains-popularity Racist Book, Camp of the Saints, Gains in Popularity], ''[[Intelligence Report]]'', March 21, 2001</ref> and in October 2015, condemned the novel as "the favorite racist fantasy of the anti-immigrant movement in the US."<ref name="splc">{{cite web|url=http://www.splcenter.org/intel/intelreport/article.jsp?sid=172|title=Intelligence Report|publisher=}}</ref> Ryan Lenz of the SPLC notes that "[t]he premise of ''Camp of the Saints'' plays directly into that idea of white genocide. It is the idea that through immigration, if it's left unchecked, the racial character and content of a culture can be undermined to the point of oblivion."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/146925/notorious-book-ties-right-far-right|title=The Notorious Book that Ties the Right to the Far Right|last=Jones|first=Sarah|date=|work=The New Republic|access-date=2018-03-28|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref>
In 2002, [[Lionel Shriver]] described the novel as "both prescient and appalling," certainly "racist" but "written with tremendous verbal energy and passion." Shriver writes that the book "gives bilious voice to an emotion whose expression is increasingly taboo in the West, but that can grow only more virulent when suppressed: the fierce resentment felt by majority populations when that status seems threatened."<ref name="shriver">[[Lionel Shriver]]: [http://www.newstatesman.com/node/190781 "Population doomsday"], ''[[New Statesman]]'', 10 June 2002, retrieved 1 December 2012</ref>
[[William F. Buckley, Jr.]] praised the book in 2004 as "a great novel" that raised questions on how to respond to massive illegal immigration,<ref name="nro">Buckley, Jr., William F. "[https://web.archive.org/web/20070430112736/http://www.nationalreview.com/script/printpage.p?ref=%2Fbuckley%2Fwfb200407231332.asp No Irish Need Apply]." ''National Review Online''. July 23, 2004</ref> and in 2014, [[Mackubin Thomas Owens]] noted Buckley's praise of it, while remarking that "Raspail was ahead of his time in demonstrating that Western civilization had lost its sense of purpose and history—its 'exceptionalism'."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/380211/camp-saints-2014-style-mackubin-thomas-owens|title=Camp of the Saints, 2014 Style? - National Review|date=13 June 2014|publisher=}}</ref> In 2005, the conservative [[Chilton Williamson]] praised the book as "one of the most uncompromising works of literary reaction in the 20th century."<ref name="williamson">{{cite book | last = Williamson | first = Chilton | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = The Conservative Bookshelf: Essential Works That Impact Today's Conservative Thinkers | publisher = Citadel Press | year = 2005 | location = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=RIq6-S9cfMQC&pg=PA279 | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-8065-2691-2 | page = 279 }}</ref>
The book returned to the bestseller list, ranking in the top 5 in bookstores in France as of March 2011.<ref name="L'Express"/> It has been referred to often by [[Steve Bannon]], U.S. President [[Donald Trump]]'s former chief strategist.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Bannon Canon: Books favored by the Trump adviser|url=http://www.newsweek.com/bannon-canon-books-trump-adviser-572835|website=Newsweek|accessdate=14 August 2017|language=en|date=23 March 2017}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{more footnotes|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox Treaty | name = Treaty establishing the European Defence Community | image = European Defence Community.png | image_width = 200px | caption = Signatory states | type = Military pact | date_signed = 27 May 1952 | date_effective = Never | condition_effective = | parties = {{Collapsible list | title = 6 | {{Flagu|Belgium}} | {{Flagu|France}} | {{Flagu|West Germany}} | {{Flagu|Italy}} | {{Flagu|Luxembourg}} | {{Flagu|Netherlands}} }} | depositor = | languages = | wikisource = Traité instituant la Communauté européenne de défense }} The '''Treaty establishing the European Defence Community''' is an unratified treaty signed on 27 May 1952 by the [[Inner Six|six 'inner']] countries of [[European integration]]; West Germany, France, Italy, and the [[Benelux]] countries. The treaty would have created a European Defence Community (EDC) with a pan-European defence force. The treaty failed to obtain ratification in the French parliament, and consequently never entered into force. Instead, West Germany was admitted into the [[Western European Union]] (WEU), a dormant successor of the 1948 [[Western Union (alliance)|Western Union]], as well as [[NATO]].
The treaty was initiated by the ''Pleven plan'', proposed in 1950 by then French Prime Minister [[René Pleven]] in response to the American call for the rearmament of [[West Germany]]. The formation of a pan-European defence architecture, as an alternative to West Germany's proposed accession to [[NATO]], was meant to harness the German military potential in case of conflict with the [[Soviet bloc]]. Just as the [[Schuman Declaration|Schuman Plan]] was designed to end the risk Germany having the economic power on its own to make war again, the Pleven Plan and EDC were meant to prevent the military possibility of Germany's making war again.
==Planned organisation== The European Defence Community would have entailed a pan-European military, divided into national components, and had a common budget, common arms, centralized military procurement and institutions. [[File:Organisation of the European Defence Community.png|thumb|center|500px|Diagram showing the functioning of the institutions provided for by the Treaty establishing the European Defence Community (EDC), the placing of Member States’ armed forces (European Defence Forces) at the disposal of the Community, and the link between the EDC and the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO).]] ===Reporting=== In this military, the French, Italian, Belgian, Dutch and Luxembourgish components would report to their national governments, whereas the West German component would report to the EDC. This was due to the fear of a return of [[Militarism#Germany|German militarism]], so it was desired that the [[German government]] would not have control over the German military. However, in the event of its rejection, it was agreed to let the West German government control its own military in any case (something which the treaty would not have provided).
== History == {{History of the European Union}} ===Background=== During the late 40s, the divisions created by the [[Cold War]] were becoming more and more evident. The United States looked with suspicion at the growing power of the [[Soviet Union|USSR]] and European states felt vulnerable, fearing a possible Soviet occupation. In this climate of mistrust and suspicion, the United States considered the rearmament of West Germany as a possible solution to enhance the security of Europe and of the whole [[Western Bloc|Western bloc]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Rise and Fall of the European Defence Community: Anglo-American Relations and the Crisis of European Defense, 1950–55|last=Ruane|first=Kevin|publisher=|year=2000|isbn=|location=|pages=1, 2|quote=|via=}}</ref> In September 1950, [[Dean Acheson]] proposed a new plan to the European states; the American plan, called ''package,'' sought to enhance NATO's defense structure, creating 12 West German divisions. However, after the destruction that Germany had caused during [[World War II]], European countries, and in particular France, were not ready to see the reconstruction of the German military.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Rise and Fall of the European Defence Community: Anglo-American Relations and the Crisis of European Defense, 1950–55|last=Ruane|first=Kevin|publisher=|year=2000|isbn=|location=|pages=4|quote=|via=}}</ref> Finding themselves in the midst of the two superpowers, they looked at this situation as a possibility to enhance the [[European integration|integration process]], trying to obviate the loss of military influence caused by the new bipolar order.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Background for the European Defence Community|journal=Political Science Quarterly|volume=68}}</ref>
===Pleven Plan=== {{Wikisource|Pleven Plan}} On 24 October 1950, France's Prime Minister [[René Pleven]] proposed a new plan, which took his name although it was drafted mainly by [[Jean Monnet]], that aimed to create a supranational [[European Army]]. With this project, France tried to satisfy America's demands, avoiding, at the same time, the creation of German divisions, and thus the rearmament of Germany.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Rise and Fall of the European Defence Community: Anglo-American Relations and the Crisis of European Defense, 1950–55|last=Ruane|first=Kevin|publisher=|year=2000|isbn=|location=|pages=4, 5|quote=|via=}}</ref><ref>Pierre Guillen, "France and the Defence of Western Europe: From the Brussels Pact (March 1948) to the Pleven Plan (October 1950)." in ''The Western Security Community: Common Problems and Conflicting Interests during the Foundation Phase of the North Atlantic Alliance,'' ed. Norbert Wigershaus and Roland G. Foerster (1993), pp. 125–48.</ref> The EDC was to include West Germany, France, Italy, and the [[Benelux]] countries. The United States would be excluded. It was a competitor to NATO (in which the US played the dominant role), with France playing the dominant role. Just as the [[Schuman Declaration|Schuman Plan]] was designed to end the risk of Germany having the economic power to make war again, the Pleven Plan and EDC were meant to prevent the same possibility. The United Kingdom refused to join.<ref>Alex May, ''Britain and Europe since 1945'' (1999) pp. 18–34.</ref>
According to the Pleven Plan, the European Army was supposed to be composed of military units from the member states, and directed by a council of the member states’ ministers.
===Negotiations and signing=== France feared the loss of national sovereignty in security and defense, and thus a truly supranational European Army could not be tolerated by Paris.<ref>{{Cite book|title = European Security and Defense Policy: From Taboo to a Spearhead of EU Foreign Policy|last = Keukeleire|first = Stephan|publisher = |year = 2009|isbn = |location = |pages = 52–53}}</ref> However, because of the strong American interest in a West German army, a draft agreement for a modified Pleven Plan, renamed the [[European Defense Community]] (EDC), was ready in May 1952, with French support. The new EDC treaty was signed on 27 May 1952.
Although with some doubts and hesitation, the United States and the six members of the [[European Economic Community|European Community]] approved the Pleven Plan. This led the way to the Paris Conference, launched in February 1951, where it was negotiated the structure of the supranational army. Among compromises and differences, on 27 May 1952 the six foreign ministers signed the Treaty of Paris establishing the European Defence Community (EDC).<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Rise and Fall of the European Defence Community: Anglo-American Relations and the Crisis of European Defense, 1950-55|last=Ruane|first=Kevin|publisher=|year=2000|isbn=|location=|pages=15|quote=|via=}}</ref>
===1954: French failure to ratify=== Despite the central role for France, the EDC plan collapsed when it failed to obtain ratification in the [[French Parliament]]. The reasons that led to the failed ratification of the Treaty were twofold, concerning major changes in the international scene, as well as domestic problems of the [[French Fourth Republic]].<ref>{{Cite journal|title=The European Defense Community in the French National Assembly: A Roll Call Analysis|journal=Comparative Politics|volume=2}}</ref> There were [[Gaullist]] fears that the EDC threatened France's [[national sovereignty]], constitutional concerns about the indivisibility of the French Republic, and fears about West Germany's remilitarization. French Communists opposed a plan tying France to the capitalist [[United States]] and setting it in opposition to the [[Communist bloc]]. Other legislators worried about the absence of the [[United Kingdom]]. The EDC went for ratification in the French National Assembly on 30 August 1954, and failed by a vote of 319 against 264. By this time, concerns about a future conflict faded with the death of [[Joseph Stalin]] and the end of the [[Korean War]]. Concomitant to these fears were a severe disjuncture between the original [[Pleven Plan]] of 1950 and the one defeated in 1954. Divergences included military integration at the division rather than battalion level and a change in the command structure putting the NATO Supreme Commander in charge of EDC operational capabilities. Italy also never ratified the treaty.<ref>{{citeweb|url=https://eeas.europa.eu/topics/common-security-and-defence-policy-csdp/5388/shaping-of-a-common-security-and-defence-policy-_en|title=Shaping of a Common Security and Defence Policy|date=2016-07-08|accessdate=2017-11-04|publisher=[[European External Action Service]]}}</ref><ref>{{citeweb|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_MEMO-17-1517_en.htm|title=Questions and Answers: the Future of European Defence|date=2017-06-07|accessdate=2017-11-04|publisher=[[European External Action Service]]}}</ref> Then French Prime Minister, [[Pierre Mendès-France]], tried to placate the treaty's detractors by attempting to ratify additional protocols with the other signatory states. These included the sole integration of covering forces, or in other words, those deployed within West Germany, as well as the implementation of greater national autonomy in regard to budgetary and other administrative questions. Britain approved of the plan in principle, but agreed to join only if the supranational element was decreased.
===Reaction=== The treaty never went into effect. Instead, after the failed ratification in the French National Assembly, Germany was admitted into NATO<ref>Josef Joffe, "Europe's American Pacifier," ''Foreign Policy'' (1984) 54#1 pp. 64–82 [https://www.jstor.org/stable/1148355 in JSTOR]</ref> and the EC member states tried to create foreign policy cooperation in the De Gaulle-sponsored [[Fouchet Plan]] (1959–1962). European foreign policy was finally established during the third attempt with [[European Political Cooperation]] (EPC) (1970). This became the predecessor of the [[Common Foreign and Security Policy]] (CFSP).
Today the [[European Union]] and [[NATO]], and formerly also the [[Western European Union]], all carry out some of the functions which was envisaged for the EDC, although none approach the degree of [[Supranationalism|supranational]] military control that the EDC would have provided for.

'''The Union of Young Fascists – Vanguard''' ({{lang-ru|Союз Юных Фашисток — Авангард}}, ''Soyuz Yunykh Fashistok — Avangard'') was the young women's youth organization of the [[Russian Fascist Party]]. It was founded in 1934 in [[Harbin]], and was open to Russian girls aged 10 to 16 years.
The main objective of the Union was "the preparation of national-minded Russian young women and girls to responsible national service based on religion, nationalism, and work".
The ideology and tactics of the Union were entirely determined by members of the Russian Fascist Party. Membership was obtained on recommendation of an existing member of the Vanguard or a member of the senior Russian Fascist Party.
The Union was divided into two groups, Junior (10 to 13 years) and Senior (13 to 16 years). Each group was divided into two categories: Second Level (Young Fascists) and First Level (Avangardistki).
Commanding officers in the Union were the Senior Source, the Senior District Commander, and Senior Divisional Commander.
The lowest structural unit in the Union was the "Focus", a group of five people. Several of these that were geographically close to each other formed a District, and together with other suburban areas or units otherwise related, they formed a Department. The head of the group was appointed by the head of the Russian Fascist Party, the others were appointed by their respective commanders.
The uniform consisted of a white blouse with a black tie and a black skirt.<ref>''The Russian Fascists: Tragedy and Farce in Exile, 1925—1945'' by John J. Stephan {{ISBN|0-06-014099-2}}</ref>

[[Christian socialism]] |position = |international = |colors = [[Red]] |colorcode = #FF0000 |flag = }} The '''United Left''' ({{lang-de|Vereinigte Linke}}) was an alliance of several [[Left-wing politics|leftist]] opposition groupings in the [[East Germany|German Democratic Republic]]. Among them were [[Christian socialism|Christian Socialists]], [[Trotskyism|Trotskyists]], adherents of the [[Titoism|Titoistic]] system of [[Workers' self-management|self-management]] and some [[Socialist Unity Party of Germany]] (SED) members, who were critical of their party's policy. ==History== Founded on October 2, 1989, only a few weeks before the fall of the [[Berlin Wall]], the United Left demanded a reformation of [[socialism]] with the stated goal of creating a free and democratic GDR. At the end of the year 1989 the party had 1500 members with focal points in [[Berlin]] and [[Halle (Saale)|Halle]]. In contrast to other East German opposition groups, the United Left received less support from Western governments and political parties. Organisational issues and internal tensions between the various ideological factions meant that the United Left only achieved limited political success during its existence. At the first free elections in the GDR in March 1990 the United Left started together with "''{{ill|Die Nelken|de}}''" ("The Carnations"), a [[Marxism|Marxist]] party. The electoral alliance with the name "''Aktionsbündnis Vereinigte Linke''" gained 0.18% of the votes and one seat in the [[Volkskammer]]. The United Left fell apart in the years after [[German reunification]], but some members were elected to the [[Bundestag]] through a party-list of the [[Party of Democratic Socialism (Germany)|PDS]] or [[Alliance 90/The Greens|The Greens]]. ==Election results== ===GDR Parliament (''Volkskammer'')=== {| class=wikitable |- !
